"At the end of the 19th century, the sentiments of Croatian and Serbian nations towards the Austrian Empire (reorganized as Austria-Hungary in 1867) were shaped by their roles within or outside the dual monarchy, pressures from assimilation, and dreams of uniting their communities. 

For Croatians, who were part of the Hungarian half of the monarchy as the Kingdom of Croatia-Slavonia, their relationship with Austria-Hungary was defined by the 1868 Nagodba (Compromise). This agreement granted limited local self-rule: a restored parliament (Sabor), use of the Croatian language in administration and schools, and control over small-scale local matters. Many Croatians initially viewed this as a step forward, ending direct Hungarian rule, but frustration grew as Hungary retained power over key areas—defense, foreign policy, tariffs, and railway building. Hungarian efforts to impose their language as the command language in Croatian army regiments sparked widespread discontent, as Croatians saw this as an attack on their cultural heritage. 

Croatian political groups reflected these divides. The People’s Party supported the Nagodba and saw Austria as a potential counterbalance to Hungarian overreach, arguing that working within the dual monarchy was the best way to protect Croatian interests. In contrast, the Party of Rights rejected the Nagodba and pushed for full self-rule, sometimes seeking Austria’s support as a temporary shield against Hungary but ultimately aiming for an independent Croatian state. A coalition of Croats and Serbs in Croatia-Slavonia formed to oppose Hungarian dominance, sharing a common desire to push back against assimilation and regain more autonomy. Ideas of uniting all South Slavs (Croats, Serbs, Slovenes) began to gain traction, with some advocating for a third component in the dual monarchy (a “Triple Monarchy”) and others dreaming of a separate state free from Austrian or Hungarian control. 

For Serbians, the picture was more fragmented. Serbs living within Austria-Hungary faced distinct challenges: in Vojvodina (a region under Hungarian rule), aggressive Hungarianization policies—banning Serbian in schools, renaming villages to Hungarian—fueled resentment. The Serbian community in Vojvodina formed groups to demand more autonomy and cultural rights, sometimes appealing to Austria for help but also maintaining strong ties to the independent Kingdom of Serbia. In Bosnia-Herzegovina, occupied by Austria-Hungary in 1878, Serbs resented the takeover even as the Austrian administration brought new infrastructure (roads, railways) and access to education. Many Bosnian Serbs saw the occupation as a barrier to joining their kin in independent Serbia. 

The independent Kingdom of Serbia, which gained full sovereignty from the Ottoman Empire in 1878, held deep hostility towards Austria-Hungary. Serbia’s core goal was to unite all Serbs into a single state, but Austria-Hungary controlled most Serb-inhabited lands outside Serbia. Austria actively opposed Serbian expansion: it forced Serbia to accept the status quo after a war with Bulgaria in 1885, imposed economic sanctions (like the 1906 “Pig War,” which banned Serbian pork imports—Serbia’s main export), and tried to isolate Serbia from other nations. These actions reinforced Serbia’s view of Austria as an obstacle to its national goals. Serbia aligned itself with Russia, a fellow Slavic power, to counter Austrian influence, and Serbian cultural movements—led by poets and the Orthodox Church—grew increasingly critical of Austria-Hungary. 

By the turn of the 20th century, the initial pragmatic acceptance of Austria-Hungary among Croats and Serbs had faded. For Croats, the failure of the dual monarchy to protect their autonomy from Hungarian overreach pushed many towards ideas of South Slav unity. For Serbs, both inside and outside the empire, the dream of uniting their community made Austria-Hungary an irreconcilable barrier. These sentiments laid the groundwork for future tensions that would shape the course of European history in the early 20th century."
